content: here in the perpetual youth of nature we
return the reason and we find cheap crafting materials pine bark has proven
itself to work really well for terrain and basis but what if you can't find it
perhaps perhaps we can use just wood instead here we have some exquisite
pieces of dead wood flying around so don't you dare make any excuses for not
making terrain
okay I'm back at the table with the wood dried and somewhat sterilized in the
oven the idea is to use this as high-quality flocking that can be used
to cover ground with stones and rubble Here I am chopping up the wood with my
professional crafting knife as long as you use slightly decayed wood it should
be easy to chop up if you for some reason are hopelessly unable to even
find old wood sticks your poor foraging skills might find some fresh wood this
is easier to whittle into strips first then chop it up there what's that
compared to the bark the wood that should do of course
the bar is much easier to chop up the cutting noises are better and you can
shape large pieces as cliffs and rocks the old wood on the other hand is easily
available even you might find some let's see how it works then next I made the
basis for my creations I got inspired to make spell effect markers that are
suitable for D&D spells or used as legendary actions for unique monsters
the basis can also be made from
cardboard in that case you want to cover up the ends and watch out for warping as
I did with the ferry portal theorem probably one of my favorites so far next
I covered the surfaces with plenty of PVA glue good then I dropped on my
chopped up wood flocking try to cover everything with a blend of small and
large bits and make sure that there's not too much sticking outside the edges
as comparison I covered up one base with my chopped up bark flocking I think the
results should be good for both flock types but we'll see then I sprayed on
diluted PVA glue I put in a spray bottle I soaked the flock as I knew I had time
to wait the next day they were fully dried everything seems to stay in place
I'll start with the big one this one will get nasty spikes first I carved
this spiky pillar from a dry but not rotten stick good enough I then carved
in some damage with the blade and then sawed it into suitable length there we
have it next additional spikes I will make these from left over spruce I
carved this pointy as well I made sure I got many good edges for later
highlighting as I did with the claws of my gold dragon made from old packages
I also added cuts into these panics I took my PVA glue and attached the big
stick first making sure the white glue is not visible I applied more of the
wood flocking and then the Spruce spikes these were easily glued on as following
apply dabs of glue first then drop on your flocking and poke in the spikes in
this way the spikes will stay upright while the glue dries make sure to gently
push down the flock as well that's good I wanted space for miniatures so I
didn't add more spikes than this I lied one more next I moved over to the
flaming sculpting the skull shall be attached to something like this cut out
from cardstock a bit tricky to cut out but I managed there I cut here so I
could get the skull in place beautiful I glued this onto the base in the same
way as I glued on the spikes now it is time to make the flames to make this I
cut out a few somewhat flame-shaped cardstock bits about three should do
with the help of some hot glue the pieces were easily put together like
this while the glue was hot I could adjust the shape of the flames I then
reinforced the tips of the cardstock by applying PVA glue with my fingers thin
cardstock bits are fragile but no more I also did the same thing here well this
piece waits I'll do something less sinister for the next base I cut out
crosses from this sheet of plastic it would be better to use something thicker
or for the sake of ease you could use cardstock I cut out a total of three
crosses I will glue them on like this but not yet Forrest admiration break
I found these pine acres they will surely be useful for something I don't
know what I will use them for but I'm sure I'll figure out something so I did
for this base I'll use a pine cone they are not actually called acres this will
be some sort of a healing fountain I just painted it yellow to begin with I
think it's time to get an airbrush soon are you regretted instead I only painted
the edges yellow that's better and a bit on the tips as well then I
followed up with some white highlights and stronger and wash on the inner
surfaces to make the yellow appear brighter I then took all bases for base
cavity the skull will not be sprayed so I removed it I covered this with a black
primer and then I continued by over brushing each piece with Brown here in
the fire skull base I did not paint in at the middle that will be the most
scorched area same thing for the spike face I did not paint on the mounds where
the spikes stick out when painting over black you might need more or brighter
paint than you think the brown here darkens when it dries over the black
base coat for variance I fully covered some stones brown and others grey there
that leads us to a gray dry brush these brushing noises will surely improve the
quality of the video this is now quite dark and cold in color
so I dry brushed with a light brown I can now see a clear difference between
bark and wood flocking the chopped wood is much sharper and has more paintable
edges perhaps because my wood bits were larger
and longer compared to the previously chopped up bark
I will now finish these individually starting with the spikes I painted the
edges of the larger spike with green
after a few layers it was good and I painted the rest as well I couldn't
paint exactly on the edges but they turned out great anyway here I dry
brushed the ground around the spikes with green and then with yellow when
doing this I brushed outwards from the spikes basically this is peasant level
object source lighting and then naturally I highlighted the edges with
the yellow as well
you can't really go wrong with these colors and it keeps the burglars out if
you're enjoying the content make sure to subscribe and like this video in the end
good this is the one I'm most excited about
I had already base painted the flame here white I started by dry brushing
this chaos wheel with metallic paint trying to keep it quite dark then I
painted the edges with silver I already started with the peasant level object
source lighting so why stop now I used a weird brush to gently tap in
some orange I applied it wherever I imagined the fire to shine then I did
similarly with yellow hmm not bad not good then I took the flame and painted
it yellow leaving the hottest parts white then I worked my way through with
oranges red and dark red good enough it's only cardstock after all i dry
brushed more yellow in the direction of the flame then figured out how to
assemble this first I placed the head then I placed a bar bit under along with
some PVA glue and managed to balance the flame skull in the nose of the skull
later I moved it in the mouth now let's retake Jerusalem with silver
crosses first I fully painted this with gunmetal
after which I dry brush the edges with silver then I used diluted blue with to
paint a smaller and Vega cross in the middle something like this I painted
with blue next quite shaky and I failed a few times before filming and I painted
the middle of the cross white done turned out quite nice even though I
can't paint cleanly I had an idea how to attach the crosses
first I applied plenty of glue where the crosses shall be placed
hmmm okay that will never work I just applied the flocking first by the way
this is dill I waited for a while and tried to poke in on the crosses hoping
that the glue would be thick enough nope I prayed for an answer I got none but
tried again the glue was now blessed by stickiness as it had dried further I was
able to get the crosses in place quite easily while I had the herbs already I
also applied the glue to this base then placed in the pine cone and dropped in
some time followed by a string cling of deal I let this dry completely then
